title: Police look into astonishing claims teen cancer patient faked his terminal illness ‘to get a free stuff from charity’
text:
Opinion TEEN ‘FAKED CANCER’ Police look into astonishing claims teen cancer patient faked his terminal illness ‘to get a free stuff from charity’ 
THE 19-year-old was handed a £1000 guitar by the charity and an all expenses paid trip to Belfast By LAUREN FRUEN Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments A TEENAGER has been accused of faking terminal cancer by a charity who allege he told lies about having the illness. 
The Clutha Trust ­charity has accused Eli Stewart of pretending to have tumours in his lungs and stomach to get a free guitar. Twitter 1 Eli Stewart, 19, is being investigated by police amid claims he lied about his terminal cancer 
The 19-year-old is said to have told the Trust – set up in the wake of the Glasgow helicopter crash – and other charities he was diagnosed with cancer two years ago. 
Since then he has been handed a £1000 guitar by the charity and an all expenses paid trip to Belfast, The Daily Record reports. 
Eli – who has been pictured with his head shaved in hospital – has also taken part on fundraising projects to help other young people. related stories NHS workers' shocking health tourism abuse exposed as we reveal scale of crisis YOU'RE TAKING THE BISCUIT! But following officials say they are yet to receive money from a gig night at Ivory Blacks nightclub in Glasgow last December. 
The Clutha Trust was founded after 10 people died at the Glasgow bar in 2013 when a police helicopter crashed through the roof. 
Founder Alan Crossan became suspicious and challenged Stewart at the end of last year. 
He said: “This wee guy appeared at the Clutha about a year ago and what we do is give kids a chance to play on a ­Sunday afternoon. He said he was terminally ill and had only six months to live. 
“It started off with cancer, then it was epilepsy, then a heart transplant – that was what really raised the alarm with me. He also said he was suffering from seizures.” 
A police spokesman said: “We can confirm we have received a ­complaint and police ­inquiries are ongoing.” 
At his home Stewart’s mum Carole, 55, said: “I’m sorry he’s not here just now.”
